title: Serena Williams Goes for History at the U.S. Open
text:
Everyone believes this is finally the moment for Serena Williams to win her record-tying 24th major title.

Williams has lost in her last three major finals, most recently at Wimbledon this summer. But heading into today’s U.S. Open final against Bianca Andreescu, Williams, 37 years old, is healthy. She’s not tired or slow, like she was for much of the season. And even when she’s not playing as well as she can, she’s impressive, as she was when she thumped Elina Svitolina, No. 5 in the world, on Thursday evening.

“It definitely wasn’t my best tennis,” Williams said.

Patrick Mouratoglou, Williams’s long-time coach, said her victory is a lock against Andreescu, who will be playing her first Grand Slam final.

“Bianca is going to win Grand Slams,” Mouratoglou said. “For me, it’s sure. But she will have to wait for the first one. She has never faced someone like Serena in her life. Not yet.”

Those are bold words, but Williams, after all, has been dominant for more than 20 years, something women’s tennis had never seen before. And Williams is more confident than she was at Wimbledon, where she had little time to prepare because of an injury.

She also seems calm and plans to stay that way, unlike at last year’s U.S. Open, where she lost to Naomi Osaka in a controversial match that ended with loud boos aimed at the chair umpire.

Still, this doesn’t mean Andreescu has no chance. She’s confident. She has a lot of options in her game, with solid serves and volleys, and pretty drop shots. Yes, Andreescu is just 19 years old, but she has jumped up the rankings all year. She said she has just one match to go and badly wants it.

“I’m sure she’s going to bring her A game,” Andreescu said. “I’m going to try to bring my A game, too. Hopefully I guess the best player may win.”

Early Friday morning, Williams worked essentially in silence. On the grounds, just eight people watched as Williams loosened up first, and then began to crush the ball. She looked faster than she has since she hurt her ankle at the Australian Open (she also recently had pain in her left knee).

Mackie Shilstone, a long-time trainer, has worked with Williams for more than 10 years. He said when he arrived here before the Open, Williams looked solid from the start.

“With any tennis player, if the knee fails you or the ankle or whatever, you’re going to start serving with your shoulder,” Shilstone said. “And it’s the beginning of downfall.”

Williams missed four straight major tournaments because of her pregnancy, and has struggled since returning to the sport after the birth of her child, Alexis Olympia Ohanian Jr., in September of 2017. Mouratoglou said Williams is remarkable in how she has recovered since Alexis’s birth.

“This takes a lot of time, both physically and mentally,” Mouratoglou said. “I think her body is the body of a top athlete again. And she hasn’t been injured since two weeks before Wimbledon, so now we had many weeks in a row.” (Mouratoglou said that the back spasms that caused her to retire in the Toronto final against Andreescu are no longer an issue.)

Andreescu has had injuries this year, too. She almost declined to play in Toronto this summer because she was rehabbing her shoulder. But once she was cleared, she began an improbable comeback. Andreescu has now won 12 matches in a row since she arrived in Toronto. And it doesn’t seem to bother Andreescu that she had won just two matches in three major events before this tournament.

Belinda Bencic, whom Andreescu beat in the semifinals, said Andreescu plays like a veteran, rather than a rookie. “She’s a very smart player on the court, plays different than other players,” Bencic said. “That’s why she’s good.”

Williams insists that she is a different player right now than the one who lost the Wimbledon final, more like her former self. More important: Despite what most people expect, Williams insists that she is not feeling extra pressure from trying to take her 24th slam and tie Margaret Court’s record.

“I literally haven’t thought about it this tournament,” Williams said. “I’ve been way more chill.”

Bianca Andreescu reacts during a match against Belinda Bencic. Photo: johannes eisele/Agence France-Presse/Getty Images

As for Andreescu, she is feisty and usually tries to control the match with power and creativity. If she falls behind early, she often adjusts her game without panicking.

”She’s a warrior and she’s a street fighter,” said Sylvain Bruneau, her coach. “She strives to compete. I strongly hope and I’m pretty confident she’s going to step [up] in the arena.”

The U.S. Open final is one thing, but any final against Williams is quite another. But Andreescu said she couldn’t wait to get started.

“[Williams] is an amazing champion on and off the court,” Andreescu said. “It’s going to be fun.”
description: Serena Williams is one win away from her 24th Grand Slam title, while 19-year-old Bianca Andreescu aims to play spoiler in Saturday’s U.S. Open women’s final.
